text: No. 28, Transportation Communication Employees Union, petitioner vs. Union Pacific Railroad Company.
Mr. Chief Justice, May it please Court.
No question about the Collective Bargaining Agreement with the clerks was not before the Adjustment Board in this proceeding.
Oh!
The record doesn't show whether the Adjustment Board had --
The record doesn't show whether they attached a copy.
There was no hearing, they had no oral hearing.
Well, I don't know if they did it in this case or not.
Was the agreement, Bargaining Agreement with the Clerk's Union in the record?
Well, I submit to Justice Stewart just asked me --
Well, you said there were lots of exhibits.
Well, I don't either.
Well, Mr. Kraemer, what is the procedure before the Board?
Oh!
On the basis of the written documents.
They don't have any witnesses.
They don't take any evidence though?
No, the only evidence as written evidence submitted by one side or the other.
Now, I'm sure there must be instances of disagreement over what may be controlling fact.
Yes.
Do they have affidavits or about an affidavit of--?
Not affidavits in the sense of testimony.
They don't any deposition -- .
Oh!
In ordinary labor arbitration, and you have got lot of experience in this, is that valid point?
No, this is quite formal.
That's what I would suppose -- .
But here they have – they follow a one ritual and one side files papers and the other side files a response.
Where?
In the Third Division, they used to --
You mean “cut that shorter”.
Oh!
How about the old common law pleading?
Almost.
Well, if the carrier argued that it was covered by clerk's agreement you would think the carrier would have something in the record?
You would think so.
To argue from what --
Yes.
You say you don't know whether it was there or not?
No.
But you say clerk's vice-president was a member of the tribunal?
Yes.
Did they have an oral argument or they just submit it on the papers?
They normally do not have an oral argument.(Voice overlap)
It's really on the pleading then --
Well, it's more than pleading, the pleading that these papers contain an argument.
Mr. Chief Justice, May it please the Court.
What expiration date is your agreement with the telegraphers?
Mr. Justice White, in the railroad industry --
(Inaudible) did get notice and change anytime they want it.
We can serve such as --
What was it?
Well, in the first place, we don't believe that it's necessary.
I get the feel where you have to readily decide this issue otherwise, you are admitting what your agreement means.
Well, I should find out to you right away.
Mr. Wilcox, did you ask the Board to bring the clerks claim?
Yes, we did.
